article.headline: LSU 82, McNeese State 79
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- After building a 21-point lead at one point, LSU almost watched it all disappear. "The last 10 minutes of that game, we invented ways to try and give it away," said LSU head coach John Brady. "It was absolutely a comedy of errors by our team. We hit a 21-point lead and played pretty good for a stretch and separated the score, but the last ten minutes we invented ways to try and let McNeese beat us." But the Tigers held on and Brandon Bass scored 27 points en route to an 82-79 win over McNeese State Monday night. After trailing by as many as six points in the first half, the Tigers (5-1) closed out the opening period on a 7-0 run and opened the second with 14 straight points to put enough distance between themselves and the Cowboys (3-3) to survive a late rally. Down 35-34 with three minutes left in the first half, Bass took a pass in the paint from Xavier Whipple and threw down a two-handed dunk to give LSU a one-point lead. McNeese State fought back to cut the lead to three late in the second half, thanks largely to a late 7-0 run, but a 3-point attempt by Edward Garriet that would have tied the game at 82 clanged off the front of the rim as time expired. "I almost fouled him, so I was like, 'If he makes it and they call the foul, Lord knows what will happen," said Antonio Hudson. "I was trying to get out of the way of the foul, but the way he was shooting I didn't even want to look." Glen Davis added 15 points and seven rebounds for LSU and Hudson had 13 points. McNeese State was led by Edward Garriet's season-high 31 points, including seven 3-pointers, while J.T. Williams scored 17 and Bryce May added 10 for the Cowboys.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
